org.hapiserver

Class URITemplate

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.hapiserver.URITemplate

  • public class URITemplate
extends java.lang.Object
    URITemplate implements a URI_Template, as described in https://github.com/hapi-server/uri-templates/wiki/Specification

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  URITemplate.EnumFieldHandler
      $(enum,values=a,b,c)
      static interface  URITemplate.FieldHandler
      Interface to add custom handlers for strings with unique formats.
      static class  URITemplate.HrintervalFieldHandler
      $(hrinterval;names=a,b,c,d) "b" → "06:00/12:00"
      static class  URITemplate.IgnoreFieldHandler
      $(x,name=sc,regex=[a|b])
      static class  URITemplate.PeriodicFieldHandler
      regular intervals are numbered: $(periodic;offset=0;start=2000-001;period=P1D) "0" → "2000-001"
      static class  URITemplate.SubsecFieldHandler
      $(subsec;places=6) "36" → "36 microseconds"
      static class  URITemplate.VersionFieldHandler
      Version field handler.

        See Also:

      • MAX_VALID_YEAR

        public static final int MAX_VALID_YEAR
        the last valid year.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NUM_TIME_DIGITS

        public static final int NUM_TIME_DIGITS
        the number of elements in an int array used to store times. The seven elements are:
        • 0: year
        • 1: month
        • 2: day
        • 3: hour
        • 4: minute
        • 5: seconds
        • 6: nanoseconds
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • URITemplate

        public URITemplate(java.lang.String formatString)
        create a new URITemplate for parsing and formatting.
        Parameters:
        formatString - URI template spec as in /tmp/data.$Y$m$d.txt

    • Method Detail

      • getVersion

        public static java.lang.String getVersion()

      • makeCanonical

        public static java.lang.String makeCanonical(java.lang.String formatString)
        convert %() and ${} to standard $(), and support legacy modes in one compact place. Asterisk (*) is replaced with $x. Note, commas may still appear in qualifier lists, and makeQualifiersCanonical will be called to remove them. Copied from Das2's TimeParser.
        Parameters:
        formatString - like %{Y,m=02}*.dat or $(Y;m=02)$x.dat
        Returns:
        formatString containing canonical spec, $() and $x instead of *, like $(Y,m=02)$x.dat

      • parse

        public int[] parse(java.lang.String timeString)
            throws java.text.ParseException
        return the timeString, parsed into start time and stop time. The result is a 14-element array, with the first 7 the start time and the last 7 the stop time.
        Parameters:
        timeString - the template string to be parsed.
        Returns:
        14 element array [ Y, m, d, H, M, S, nano, Y, m, d, H, M, S, nano ]
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - when a number is expected, or patterned not matched.
        See Also:
        parse(java.lang.String, java.util.Map)

      • parse

        public int[] parse(java.lang.String timeString,
                   java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> extra)
            throws java.text.ParseException
        return the timeString, parsed into start time and stop time. The result is a 14-element array, with the first 7 the start time and the last 7 the stop time. The output will be decomposed into year, month, and day even if year, day-of-year are in the time string.
        Parameters:
        timeString - string in the format described by the template.
        extra - extension results, like $(x,name=sc) appear here.
        Returns:
        14 element array [ Y, m, d, H, M, S, nano, Y, m, d, H, M, S, nano ]
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - when a number is expected, or patterned not matched.
        See Also:
        if day-of-year is needed., which can be used when extra arguments are not needed.

      • getExternalContext

        public int getExternalContext()
        return the number of digits, starting with the year, which must be provided by some external context. For example, data_$j.dat has an external context of 1 because there is no year field, and data_$d.dat would be 2 because the year and month are provided externally. Note the modifier Y= can be used to provide the context within the URI template.
        Returns:
        the external context implied by the template.

      • setContext

        public void setContext(int[] externalContextTime)
        set the context time. The number of digits copied from externalContextTime is determined by the state of externalContext.
        Parameters:
        externalContextTime - the context in [ Y, m, d, H, M, S, nanos ]

      • formatRange

        public static java.lang.String[] formatRange(java.lang.String template,
                                             java.lang.String startTimeStr,
                                             java.lang.String stopTimeStr)
                                      throws java.text.ParseException
        For convenience, add API to match that suggested by https://github.com/hapi-server/uri-templates/blob/master/formatting.json . Note if start and end appear in the template, then just one formatted range is returned.
        Parameters:
        template - the template
        startTimeStr - the beginning of the interval to cover
        stopTimeStr - the end of the interval to cover
        Returns:
        the formatted times which cover the span.
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - when a number is expected, or patterned not matched.

      • formatRange

        public static java.lang.String[] formatRange(java.lang.String template,
                                             java.lang.String startTimeStr,
                                             java.lang.String stopTimeStr,
                                             java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> extra)
                                      throws java.text.ParseException
        For convenience, add API to match that suggested by https://github.com/hapi-server/uri-templates/blob/master/formatting.json, and allowing for extra named fields to be passed in. Note if start and end appear in the template, then just one formatted range is returned. This works by formatting and parsing the time ranges, stepping through the sequence.
        Parameters:
        template - the template
        startTimeStr - the beginning of the interval to cover
        stopTimeStr - the end of the interval to cover
        extra - extra named parameters
        Returns:
        the formatted times which cover the span.
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - when the initial parsing cannot be done.

      • format

        public java.lang.String format(java.lang.String startTimeStr,
                               java.lang.String stopTimeStr)
        return a list of formatted names, using the spec and the given time range.
        Parameters:
        startTimeStr - iso8601 formatted time.
        stopTimeStr - iso8601 formatted time.
        Returns:
        formatted time, often a resolvable URI.

      • format

        public java.lang.String format(java.lang.String startTimeStr,
                               java.lang.String stopTimeStr,
                               java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> extra)
        return a list of formatted names, using the spec and the given time range.
        Parameters:
        startTimeStr - iso8601 formatted time.
        stopTimeStr - iso8601 formatted time.
        extra - extra parameters
        Returns:
        formatted time, often a resolvable URI.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Usage: java -jar dist/UriTemplatesJava.jar --formatRange --range='1999-01-01/1999-01-03' --template='http://example.com/data_$(d;pad=none).dat'
        Parameters:
        args - the command line arguments.
